intro: Themistoclesia dependens, commonly known as the hanging mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant that grows on the branches of host trees, primarily in tropical and subtropical regions. It belongs to the family Viscaceae and is characterized by its evergreen leaves and small, inconspicuous flowers. The plant lacks chlorophyll and relies on its host for water and nutrients, while also deriving some photosynthetic ability from its own leaves. Its fruits are small, fleshy berries that contain seeds coated in a sticky substance to aid in attachment to potential host trees. Due to its parasitic nature, it can have significant ecological impacts on its host species.
